values:
This was a full week of subbing for my master teacher, with Thursday being our seminar day. Our schedule at school is crazy this time of year. We are trying to fit everything in before the end of the school year, and somehow it does not seem possible! I am relieved to know that we finished the TOS test, which other first grade teachers are just starting. There are now three weeks left of teaching Houghton Mifflin, with the last full week for the final summative test. I am concerned about getting the summative done that week, because of all the other events. There is a field trip, talent show and band show, not to mention my absence on Thursday. Somehow, I will have to juggle things around to get it done!
            I have almost finished teaching my science unit and will be giving the post assessment on Monday. I have started working on my integrated unit and would like to begin teaching it this week. The whole unit is planned out, it is a matter of writing all of the lessons! This whole weekend, I worked on my unit, my 283 paper and other assignments for seminar. Only three more weeks until everything is due! I will be very relieved when I am done with everything.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/5774.html

This week, was Mrs. A's last week with the students before going on maternity leave. We finished everything that had to be done on her last day, which was Tuesday. I subbed for her on Wednesday so she could go to her doctor appointments. She was supposed to be there on Thursday, but ended up going into labor and had the baby on Thursday afternoon. When I arrived on Friday, the kids were wild. Apparently, the sub they had the day before could not handle them, a few of the other teachers told me this. I spent the day on Friday trying to get them back on track! I know I will be doing this on every Friday after they have their Thursday substitute. 
            We did not have grade level this Friday, because there was nothing pressing, according to Mrs. F, our grade level rep. Instead, I spent the time grading all of their tests and changing the focus wall for the next week. I was also able to get their homework packets completed. I still need to record their grades in the grade book. I feel comfortable taking over, because Mrs. A is very organized. It also helped that I have been in a first grade classroom since January.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/5422.html

This week was busy and full of long days. I am finding that as more time goes by, the longer the days are and the more work there is to do. I had doctor appointments, four full days of teaching, signing papers for my new house, a hair appointment, a wedding, seminar at UCR and our Cinco de Mayo celebration at West Riverside. This week felt very busy, but my next week seems just as busy! Mrs. A will still be at school on Monday and Tuesday so I will have a couple more days with her help. We finished all of the important testing and the bubbling and scoring that goes along with it. Mrs. A wanted to finish the yearbooks she made for the students and bring their pictures for the Mother's Day craft. Just knowing that all of the testing is finally done with is a huge relief!
          The grade level meeting was interesting on Friday. We discussed the SMART goal that we had set for this quarter. Students are having difficulty with reading time. We gave a pre assessment, in which the average ranges from 69%-74% for all the first grade classes. All of the first grade classes will be doing various things, such as worksheets and using clocks to help our students grasp the concept. We will then give the students a post assessment to see if they have made any gains.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/5241.html

This was a long week of testing that was tiring for the students and me. Mrs. A is trying to get the summative and the District TOS tests out of the way before she leaves. I was able to begin teaching my science unit in the afternoon. The students are so excited to learn about insects and they have so many good questions. I think because there is so little time for science and social studies, anything related is something new and exciting for them. I was surprised how well they did on the pre assessment; it tells me that they know somewhat about insects. It is actually good timing to be teaching the science unit now, because it breaks up their day from testing. I will be happy when testing is over, but then again report cards will be right around the corner. 
            I started feeling sick on Wednesday while at school. I went home and slept, hoping this would help. All that night my ears were hurting and my throat got worse. I went to the Urgent Care on Thursday to find out I had an ear infection and strep. They gave me antibiotics that gave me an allegeric reaction, which was not fun. So, I have had an interesting week. We had the day off on Thursday to work on integrated unit, instead I was sick.   I am now trying to get caught up on all of my school work!!!
http://borden321.livejournal.com/4880.html

This seemed like a very long week, even though I only had three days of student teaching and seminar. I think everyone had a little trouble getting back into the routine after spring break. I got back into town late Monday night from Chicago and had to do laundry and cleaning! When I arrived at school on Tuesday, Mrs. A informed me that she is already dilating, so she could go into labor sooner than expected. The rest of the week we spent time going over routines and she was showing me where everything I need is located. We will begin the District testing and summative testing this coming week. She is starting early so it can be done before she leaves. Unfortunately, I have not been able to do a lot of teaching because of report cards and testing. I did substitute all day on Wednesday, which went well. Mrs. A has agreed that I will teach whenever possible so the students can get used to me. It's just a matter of getting through testing, which is the top priority before she leaves! 
            I have been able to get to know the students pretty well in my two weeks in the classroom. As in any classroom, there are a few behavior students and a few very low students. Unlike my last placement, there are not any RSP students and only two that go to speech. Only one student with a minor asthma condition, he does not have an inhaler at school. I have asking Mrs. A tons of questions so I am ready once she leaves. I feel her students are much better behaved than my last placement. Mrs. A is very consistent with her disciplining and the students respect her. I am really liking her teaching style. She is very calm and the students love her, but she can be strict when needed. I know I mentioned this last week, but I am finding that her style works really well with her students. I also love that she teaches them social skills such as washing their hands or tying their shoes. I think this placement is a great way for me to spend my last couple of month's student teaching!
http://borden321.livejournal.com/4728.html

This was a long week that I was able to get acquainted with my new placement. I spent four full days in Mrs A's classroom and a full day at seminar. Now it is finally spring break, but I do not feel the break! I am very close to completing my science unit and it is my goal to have it done before the end of spring break. I am also very excited about my integrated unit. While the students were testing on Friday, I was walking around monitoring and then stopped to thumb through the social studies book. It was while I was thumbing through that I found my topic- Holidays! Once I saw it, I new I wanted to pick this topic. I was actually very excited and told Mrs. A and a few other cohort members that day. I was having a hard time picking a topic, but I am now very excited about my unit. 
            I am really liking my new placement with Mrs. A. I am finding that she is very calm and relaxed. I have found during my last placements that I tend to take on my master teachers attitude in the room. I am not saying that I teach just like them, but I feel that I have tended to take on their attitude in the classroom. Mrs. A is very soft and calm, but has control of the classroom.   She has been teaching for five years, but she seems very comfortable in the classroom. I am also very impressed with the social skills she teaches the students. She is always having then tie their laces or wash their hands after blowing their nose and pick up after themselves. I feel she is teaching them great life skills that are critical to begin this early on. I am excited to continue learning from her and feel thankful to be able to be placed with three different teachers, so I can learn from all of them.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/4409.html

Well, this week was very short for me, as I was not feeling well. I student taught on Wednesday and Friday and had seminar on Thursday. This was my last week in Mrs S's classroom. We had a little party on Friday for my last day. The students are all sad that I am leaving but I explained I would still see them as I was only going a few doors down. The students went around and said something nice to me, it was really sweet. I am sad to be leaving but excited to be with yet another teacher!
         The grade level meeting went well on Friday. We talked about the upcoming field trips that were available. All are free and walking distance, as the District cut all field trips not already funded. The first grade team has the option of going to Flabob Airport, Stater Bros. and the library. They all sound fun and I think the students would enjoy them. The team made it sound as if they wanted to fit in as much as possible, as there is not a lot to do the last couple of weeks. I am looking forward to any of the field trips they decide to do. We also looked at the items that would need to be sent to the print shop for next year. I did not think about them having to send it out this early. There was quite of bit of discussion as to what they wanted to use next year. It is nice to see how closely they work together as a team.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/4160.html

This week was a short week, but felt like a long week! I subbed for my master teacher all day Tuesday and then student taught in the morning on Wednesday and then subbed again Wednesday afternoon. Not to mention I had a final for Education 177A on Tuesday night at 7pm. I won't complain because I am finally done with PACT and hopefully never have to think about it again. The whole time I was working on it, I never thought it would be done. Not that it is done, I keep going back on G-Star to make sure I am really done with it! I figure that if I was able to finish it with my short time period, I can definitely finish every thing for the last quarter. My next big project is my science unit, which I started tonight and plan to have done by March 27th. I would love to be able to go to Mrs A's room knowing that I have that completed. 
            It was nice to go back to Mrs S's classroom this week; I actually missed the students. They were so happy to see me, which made me feel good. I was able to continue math with them using the coins. Mrs. S only finished a couple more lessons in chapter 7 after I left. I think she went back and finished chapter 6. The students started with the quarters, which is what they had been asking me about since I started teaching the money chapter. We were able to use the bag of coins and do some hands on activities, which they love. On Tuesday when I subbed all day, the morning aide did not show up for language arts, therefore I had to come with an extra activity for students. I was able to have them make a little book, making sure to note the sequence of events, which is their comprehension skill for the week. They thought is was great. They were able to make a title page of their own and we wrote the beginning and middle together, while they wrote their own ending. I think it went well.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/3943.html

This week was my last week with Mrs. A's class and I will be returning to Mrs S's room on Tuesday to sub all day. I am looking forward to spending two more weeks with her class, before moving on to Mrs A's room. I feel as if I am getting to know all of the first graders! The students from Mrs S's room miss me and are coming up to give me hugs. I am happy to spend a couple more weeks with them before having to learn about a completely new classroom. I cannot believe how fast this year has gone by! I feel as if graduation day is right around the corner. I just hope to have a job by then!!!
            I am close to finishing PACT, only a few more minor things. It is a huge relief to be so close to finishing. Now I need to start my science unit; I hope to have it done before Jurupa's Spring Break. I know that once we return from Spring Break, in no time Mrs. A will be gone and I will be in charge. I think that going to Jodi's room actually helped prepare me for what I will be doing once Mrs. A leaves.  I am glad that I was able have that two week experience.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/3761.html

Well, I began subbing for a teacher who is still out on maternity leave.  I am glad to get the experience before I take over for Mrs. A, when she goes on maternity leave. I am enjoying the first graders, but they take a lot out of me! I come home and I am exhausted. It is very different from the sixth graders, which were so independent.  However, the first graders are so sweet, just very active. This school year has gone by so fast and I feel as if it is almost over. It will be such a rewarding feeling to finally be done.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/3549.html

I am finally done teaching PACT! A huge relief, but I still have to finish all of my commentaries, along with everything else for seminar, EDUC 320B and EDUC 177A. The end of the quarter is approaching fast, but I am feeling confident I will have it all done. On Friday, it was decided that I would not be teaching my science unit in my current placement. I would have liked to have taught it with Mrs. S's students but I will have to wait until my next placement. I have really enjoyed my time in Mrs. S's classroom and I will be sad to leave. She has provided me with valuable information and has been a great mentor. I feel grateful to have had my second placement with her and will continue to enjoy what little time I have left with her. I am excited to move on to Mrs. A's classroom, as this will provide me with yet another perspective on teaching. So far, I have seen two teachers and have learned from both of them. I am sure I will gain useful insights from Mrs. A as well.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/3282.html

This week was a relief to get through.  I only have one PACT lesson left to present on Tuesday.  I am so close to being done with teaching PACT, but still have to complete all of the commentaries. As least I am closer to being done than I was last week! I was a little disappointed with the students' behavior on my day of taping. I did a group activity with them and they were so excited with the game they were a little wound up. I guess the important thing is that they were actually engaged in the lesson and learned the concept. Even my master teacher was impressed with how much they enjoyed the lesson and commented that they may ace the post assessment. However, I have found that when you think they get a concept, they still can bomb a test! I hope they do well, because I have put a lot of time into PACT. Truthfully, I hope they ace everything, all year long, but that is wishful thinking. 
            I have been having fun teaching the students my PACT lessons and they seem to enjoy the time and effort I have put into the lessons. Each student received a bag of coins that they have been using throughout the lessons. They will continue to use these coins throughout chapter 7-money. I also began math journals with the students and it is going very well. The students are enjoying the quick assessment of three problems they must answer in their own personal journal. They have also been intrigued with the part where they can draw or write anything they want related to the math lesson for the day. It is refreshing to see how many try so hard to come up with something clever. As much work as PACT has been it is definitely rewarding.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/2911.html

I began feeling better this week, other than the allergic reaction I had to my medication! I student taught my normal three full days and attended seminar on Thursday. I was able to discuss and plan my PACT lessons with my master teacher and will be teaching it this coming week. I am very anxious to begin teaching my PACT lessons. I will be happy once it is all over with. Other than a few minor setbacks, I feel ready to begin teaching my PACT lessons this week. 
            This was the first week of only having to write up one formal lesson plan. I have been teaching other lessons which mostly consist of Language Arts. I have been talking about my science unit with my master teacher. I will probably teach an insect/animal unit which is in their science books. She seems excited about having me teaching a science unit with the students. I think the students will also enjoy it. The other day I had a student tell me that she wanted to learn all about butterflies. Other students are always showing me pictures of animals and insects; these topics seem to interest them. I am sure they will enjoy the science unit. I will begin working on this once I complete teaching PACT.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/2766.html

Well, this was a short week for me because of the nasty head cold that I have! I subbed a half day on Monday, student taught on Tuesday and Wednesday, and then starting feeling sick on Wednesday night. I did not attend seminar on Thursday or student teach on Friday. Since I was feeling sick and stuck at home, I actually got a lot organized. I was also able to begin and almost complete my PACT lessons and Task 1. I hope to complete Task 2 next weekend, as I will begin teaching on February 19th. Just the fact that I have finally started working on PACT is a huge relief for me. It is great that everyone else has already taught their PACT lessons, because I am able to get suggestions. I cannot wait until I am completely finished with PACT. I will then be moving on to more assignments that are just as much work!!!
       M had an interesting week as usual. When I subbed on Monday, his father was there waiting to speak with Mrs. S. He just came last week and talked to her, but since seeing M's test scores on Friday, he felt he should come again. I told him Mrs. S was gone for the day. He came back the following day and spoke with Mrs. S. He and his wife are very concerned with his behavior and low performance. Mrs. S is very pleased that they are so concerned and involved. She informed that this year she has a pleasantly unusual group of parents. They are all very involved and want to know everything that goes on. Mrs. S is very happy about this, which I think any teacher would be. A had a good week and continues to improve academically. After doing the report cards over the weekend, Mrs. S saw how much she has improved. She actually received the principal's award on Friday for improvement. A definitely deserved it and getting this award I am sure will motivate her to work harder.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/2333.html

This week was a long of week of testing and getting caught up for report cards. The children really do get tired of all the testing, not mention it drives us crazy too! I think I was a big help to Mrs. S as far getting things scored and recorded. I was able to teach lessons while she called students to do certain tests. They still have a few tests to take next week, but for the most part, they are done. Luckily, the weather was ok this week and the children only had to stay in for one day. It really does make a difference with the weather. I think it is hard on everyone- students and teachers when you are stuck in the classroom all day! Hopefully, we will have nice weather for this next week. 
            This week because of all the testing, we were able to do some fun activities with the students to break up the monotony. Students learned about penguins and made their own free cut penguins. They were really cute and both Mrs. S and I were surprised how well they did. I also got a chance to read them a groundhog's day story that I got from seminar. The students loved the story and had so many good questions. When I was done, they got to draw a picture from the story; they loved it. I think a break from all the routines is good for all of us!
http://borden321.livejournal.com/2160.html

This week was a good week and I feel as if I am getting used to my new classroom. When gathering my papers to turn in for seminar on Thursday, I saw how nice it is to have an organized master teacher. The organization of my new master teacher is making it great for my writing my lesson. I now actually have time to plan fun lessons and come up with my own ideas. I am getting to know all of the students and their parents, which is nice.  Mrs. S seems thrilled to have me in her classroom. She has created reading groups, caught up on her testing and even gotten her classroom organized. It is nice to feel like I am helping her with her classroom. 
         As far as my two focus students this week, M had some excitement. He was acting up this week and got in trouble a few times. One day he pulled his card for misbehaving and another day he had to move his desk and sit by himself. I do not see his punishments helping to improve his behavior; we are going to have to think of new strategies to deal with M's behavior. I score all the tests on Friday's and he did not do well on any of his tests. Mrs. S noted that his mother was going to be very upset. Apparently, M's mother becomes very emotional when he misbehaves or performs poorly on class work.  A on the other hand did not have much excitement this week. She was present all the days I was there and followed along with her work. I noticed she can do the work but needs extra time. She was almost one of the last one's to finish her journal on Friday. She did an ok job but it took her almost twenty minutes longer than the rest of the class. She seems to do ok with math and struggles with Language Arts. If I have the time, I try to provide her with assistance.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/1889.html

Well this was my first week of actually teaching lessons for my new classroom placement. It is a lot different from teaching my sixth graders. A lesson that realistically thinking would only take ten minutes, actually takes between forty-five minutes to one hour. There is a whole new set of rules that I have to take into consideration with the first graders. The Houghton Mifflin Teacher's Edition does give some good ideas that I have been able to work with when teaching my class. Fortunately, I have my wonderful master teacher that has a wealth of experience that is always willing to give suggestions. I have been exhausted at the end of the day, because these little ones keep me on my toes! I am looking forward to the rest of my time in this placement. 
 
      Lastly, my two focus students for the week! Martin's behavior is always a little out of control. Mrs. S moved all of the students around and put them all on behavior contracts because they are all misbehaving. Martin is just a little extra rowdy. If I see, he is on task I try to give him a positive comment, so he knows this is the correct behavior. I also try to give him little assignments to keep him busy and out of trouble. Martin is bright and I think he gets bored in the classroom. Alexis, my other focus students left early on Tuesday for a doctor's appointment and never returned that day. On the other two days I was present she behaved very well, but has difficulty keeping up with the class work. She leaves for about a half hour on Wednesdays and goes to a reading group, she seems excited about the reading group. I think she does better in a smaller, slower paced setting. I am finding it difficult to go so slow for Alexis and one or two others that struggle to keep up. I will have to find strategies to help me with this issue.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/1660.html

This week we came back from winter vacation and I started my new placement with Mrs. S. I am now with a first grade classroom, which is much different from my sixth graders. I am excited about my new placement and hope that it will work out well. There are only twenty students in the classroom, which is much different from the thirty-two students I was used to in Mr. C's room. Of these twenty students, there are a handful that seem very rambunctious! I have observed and substitute taught other first grade classrooms that were much more organized and had only one or two active students. I am sure I will find challenges when teaching this group of students, compared to my sixth graders. Next week will be my first week of teaching lessons, which will be fun. I am looking forward to the next few months with this classroom. 
            I attended the grade level meeting for the first grade team on Friday. For the first portion of the meeting, they were going over a math portfolio project that was not pertinent to us; Mrs. F advised me she would let me know when they were done with that portion, so I could join them. During this time, I helped Mrs. L  with some of the classroom projects she was working on. I also browsed Mrs. F's classroom, in which I realized how organized she was. She has a great classroom, with so much to look at and for the students to interact with, I was really impressed with her classroom. Once the teachers were done with their math project, the student teachers joined the meeting. We discussed ELO classes after school. I expressed being interested in teaching an ELO class. Miss S and one of the other first grade teachers will also be teaching ELO classes. I will be teaching fluency on Tuesday and Wednesday, which I am looking forward to. I just hope that it does not interfere with my planning time with Mrs. S as she explained that she does not stay very late or get to school very early. The two days I will be teaching ELO are my student teaching days and my other student teaching day, is Friday, which is when we have grade level and Mrs. S  leaves early for a standing doctor's appointment. I am sure we will be able to make time to plan somewhere and Monette seems very excited about helping me. 
            As far as my two new focus students, I have decided to observe Martin for my behavior student. Within five minutes in the classroom, you will know which student is Martin. He is very active but also a very bright student. As much as he drives you crazy, you cannot help but love him!!! It will be very interesting to write about Martin every week. As far as my other focus student, I changed my mind from my initial pick and I will be observing Alexis. When entering some test scores from Friday I noticed that she had some low grades in both math and language arts. I have also noticed that she has a little trouble paying attention in class sometimes. When doing my very informal focused observation and learning/interest survey I learned that Alexis was in some sort of accident when she was little and her mother tried to explain to Mrs. S her medical issues, but her mother had difficulty explaining. Mrs. S explained that she may have a blood clot and her mother said she gets terrible headaches because of this. Mrs. S did note her starring off into space during class, which I had already noticed. I think Alexis will be a perfect focus student to observe.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/1287.html

This week we did not have grade level meetings, as teachers are to be working on their grades. Next week we have parent teacher conferences. There are only a few students in the class that have a primary language of English, therefore only a handful of conferences that I could choose from to attend. Luckily, on Thursday morning before seminar there are two conferences that will be in English, so I will attend those two meetings. It will be interesting to see Mr. Castro's interaction with the parents one on one. The first conference I will be attending is for Amy, one of my focus students. It will be interesting to observe this conference as she is having difficulties academically and behaviorally. One the other hand the next conference I will be present for is with Martin parents, which he is the opposite. Martin is well behaved and does very well academically. I am glad that I will be able to see Mr. Castro's interaction with the parents of two different types of students. 
            It was interesting to see how many of the teachers were scrambling to get their grades ready. Even some of the more organized teachers seemed to have very little done. It made me realize that no matter how organized I am, I may be doing this myself next year. I did stay and help Mr. Castro with some recording of grades and I was able to see how he did his grades. It is always good to see how different people do things as it will me give me ideas for next year. This is something I will also be able to observe my next master teacher do, which will give me another perspective. As much as I love Mr. Castro's classroom I am looking forward to moving to a primary grade with a new teacher. I feel another perspective on certain aspects will be very beneficial. I am also looking forward to the younger students with less attitudes. Of course, with anything, there is give and take and having the younger students with less attitude also means they will require more assistance with everything!
http://borden321.livejournal.com/1137.html

This week was another interesting week of subbing all three of my student teaching days! I am also subbing this coming Monday and Tuesday.  In this month, I will have subbed a total of eight days for my master teacher. I am enjoying the time alone with my students, and also developing my classroom management skills. Much like I saw last week, the students behave much differently with me than Mr. Castro. I am using this time to work on classroom management skills, but still feeling that it will be very different once I have my own classroom. Now thinking about it, I am happy to have started out with sixth graders, because I figure if I can control them, once I move to primary it will be easy. At least this is what I am hoping!!! I am looking forward to my days of subbing next week.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/888.html

Well, this was a tough week for me- I was sick, my husband was gone, first week of lesson plans, and first week of school at UCR. I survived this week, even after getting a nail in my tire after seminar on Thursday.  I'm sure there will be many more weeks like this to come in the next few months. Now that we have begun writing our lesson plans, I have learned a couple things. First, do not always trust the book on giving good examples for the students. On both of my math lessons, I used the Houghton Mifflin example from the book and the students looked at me with much confusion. I had to come up with a different way to explain it to them. So, I learned not to rely on the teacher's manual to provide the best example and always try to have a back-up plan. Next, I learned that I actually do much better teaching on the spot without a lesson plan. Each time I taught my lesson that I thoroughly planned out and wrote, I got nervous and something always went wrong. Even, Mr. Castro noted that I need to become more relaxed when in front of the students, like when I teach on the spot lesson. I think the idea of a lesson plan being so formal and knowing he is watching me and taking notes makes me nervous.  I will have to come up with some way of becoming more relaxed.
http://borden321.livejournal.com/724.html
